{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3562997,"name":"Tom","username":"Zook","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zook/{size}/252720_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T16:06:40.543Z","cooked":"

It was a grim mood last night as the team weighed our upgraded robot.
123.5lbs.

Onshape said just over 100lbs. Which I knew wasn’t right, but the climber was weighed, the algae scorer was weighed… the robot weight from our first regional was known. I was guessing close to 115, but 123.5?

Looking through the cad I did see some missing spark max controllers. Ok, add them in.
There was some missing chain. Ok, a pound or two.
All together that only accounted for 111lbs (according to Onshape mass properties).

Then it hit me: there’s no wire in the CAD! Asking around people told me to assume 10-15% of the robot weight is wiring related.

Well, 111lbs/123.5lbs is about 9%. Crap. I should have known better after 15 years of FRC.

Let this be a lesson to all of you: copper wire with thick rubber insulation has mass, plan on it being 10% of robot weight.

I really hope FIRST brings back 125 as the robot weight next year. I understand this was done to reduce kinetic energy and forces during impacts but its causing a lot of situations like this.

If you have a lift with a lot of components at the end of it…that weight can add up REAL fast.

I don’t see these “situations” as being all that detrimental to the program as a whole.

Weight Management! Its an engineering challenge!

I actually like the 115lb weight limit because it makes it harder to package everything into the weight limit so that way teams need to prioritize what they want to be able to do. I don’t think I’ve seen a robot that can do all elements of the game as well as teams have been able to do everything in previous years.

This is generally a much more important thing to consider in games that incentivize the design of elevators, long arms, etc.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T16:44:31.446Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":673,"readers_count":672,"score":164.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496342,"topic_slug":"10-for-wire-weight","display_username":"Bailey","primary_group_name":"VEX","flair_name":"VEX","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/f/b/fbf8d6ace815b6285a91d1dedb54a63db4c60840.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":56,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20709,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"VEX Robotics | 148 Mentor | Formerly 195&125"},"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563041,"name":"Chris Cross","username":"WayCoolSuperDude","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/waycoolsuperdude/{size}/171772_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T16:46:44.767Z","cooked":"

Our students always laugh when we start weighing the total robot as components get built and attached but before wiring anything up. We always throw on 2-3 full spools of usually 12 gauge wire in with everything else on the scale. Then they are amazed when the robot weighs about that amount in the end.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T16:46:44.767Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":632,"readers_count":631,"score":231.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":496342,"topic_slug":"10-for-wire-weight","display_username":"Chris Cross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38318,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Neither cool nor super."},"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563043,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T16:47:14.298Z","cooked":"
Zook:

Looking through the cad I did see some missing spark max controllers. Ok, add them in.
There was some missing chain. Ok, a pound or two.

On this train of stuff that’s easy to forget about. Bolts… Both weight and clearances of the heads/nuts/washers. If the students grab a different material bolt than the one you accounted for in CAD, etc. I don’t imagine this is 10% of a robots overall weight though, never weighed it all seperately so maybe it is.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T16:49:32.964Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":596,"readers_count":595,"score":214.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":496342,"topic_slug":"10-for-wire-weight","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563073,"name":"Dave Morrison","username":"davemorrison","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/8dc957/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T16:57:57.182Z","cooked":"

We had a similar challenge and found calculating using the manufacturer wire weight specs helpful (such as .045 lbs/ft for our 10ga). We double checked by weighing a 100ft spool to confirm they were accurate. This let us have a decent wiring estimate in our weight plan. Remember most power wires are run in pairs and the spec weight is for a single wire. We were closer to 5 lbs than 10, but we kept wire length in mind while wiring.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T16:57:57.182Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":543,"readers_count":542,"score":138.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496342,"topic_slug":"10-for-wire-weight","display_username":"Dave Morrison","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74509,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/9","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563088,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T17:04:38.683Z","cooked":"
Jwal:

Weight Management! Its an engineering challenge!

Solved Problem.

Just make an FRC robot FTC scale

On a serious note, unless you need the robot perimeter or wheelbase, shrink wrapping will free up more weight than you may expect.

Season robot!","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/11","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563163,"name":"Chase Webster","username":"Cowette","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cowette/{size}/225237_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T18:18:21.095Z","cooked":"

we’re somehow able to get away w/ our wire only being about 5%~ of the robot weight. Not sure how but just in case its our wire somehow being light we use the bntechgo silicone wire

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T18:18:21.095Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":400,"readers_count":399,"score":80.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496342,"topic_slug":"10-for-wire-weight","display_username":"Chase Webster","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66306,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7312 T3"},"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/12","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563281,"name":"Tom","username":"Zook","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zook/{size}/252720_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T19:45:58.721Z","cooked":"

Our robot (minus bumpers and battery) was 90lbs at our week 1 event. But only did L1-3 and ground algae. So we were fine with the 115lbs, too!

The engineering challenge is definitely making multipurpose systems. Trying to make single-use mechanisms and do everything is just too heavy.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T19:45:58.721Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":323,"readers_count":322,"score":69.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496342,"topic_slug":"10-for-wire-weight","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":66322,"username":"scimn27","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/50afbb/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4276 nice mentor"},"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/13","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563336,"name":"Liam Fay","username":"Liam_Fay","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/liam_fay/{size}/221140_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T20:18:10.451Z","cooked":"
Jwal:

Weight Management! Its an engineering challenge!

This. Different design challenges, whether it be stacking boxes, climbing a rope, or shooting balls, are applicable to different applications of real world engineering, but weight management is applicable to pretty much every one.

The current plan is to just bring everything and get weighed in under I109 rules. Then decide if we want to swap out mechanisms based on needs. Probably won’t even come to use, but better to be prepared.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T20:45:52.952Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":267,"readers_count":266,"score":53.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":496342,"topic_slug":"10-for-wire-weight","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4276 nice mentor"},"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/15","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563496,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T21:12:10.514Z","cooked":"

We always try to account for this when getting CAD weight by adding 10 lbs or so. This year, our CAD robot needed to weigh between 100 and 105 lbs for us to be happy that powder coat, fasteners, and wire wouldn’t put us over.

We were surprised that after building it, we were only 4-5 lbs heavier than CAD this year. Part of that comes from us modeling 3D-printed parts as solid, but we don’t think there is 5 lbs of that extra mass in the robot model. That may mean we had some material properties set incorrectly that we haven’t found. We also modeled more fasteners in places this year, but we didn’t model any rivets.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T21:12:10.514Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":235,"readers_count":234,"score":52.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496342,"topic_slug":"10-for-wire-weight","display_username":"AllenGregoryIV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":10647,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515"},"post_url":"/t/10-for-wire-weight/496342/16","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563500,"name":"Dan","username":"theworkshope","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theworkshope/{size}/194375_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T21:15:22.213Z","cooked":"

We normally start with a spreadsheet in the first week, and throw in all the known components, typically off the shelf that have masses. Then we can estimate the rest based on prior years of similar things and usually get pretty close. This year we were over a few pounds on some sub-assemblies, under a few pounds on others, and it all worked out about right. 112 lb robot, 12 lb estimated electrical non-accounted in CAD from our spreadsheet.

I’m always skeptical of the 3D printed mass tool, I feel like every part even when I set it to 100% infill is underselling the mass. I wish to find a better estimate for printed parts.
